COSIHB Package¶

IO Module¶

IO class for COS instrument handbook plotting. Can be used to read FITS image and tabular data.

Created on Mar 18, 2009

@author: Sami-Matias Niemi (niemi@stsci.edu) for STScI

class SamPy.plot.COSIHB.IO.COSHBIO(path, output)¶

IO class for COS instrument handbook plotting. Can be used to read FITS image and tabular data as well as ASCII data. As the path of the files is given in the constructor, this is only useful if the data is in same folder... (should be changed?)

ASCIITable(file, comment='#')¶

A simple function for reading data from a file into a table. Comment lines and empty lines are skipped.

FITSImage(file, extension)¶

Reads FITS image data to an array. Returns data as a NumPy array.

FITSTable(file, extension=1)¶
Reads FITS table to an array...
Returns data as a numpy array
Header(file, extension)¶
HeaderKeyword(file, extension, keyword)¶

A simple function to pull out a header keyword value.

writeToASCIIFile(data, outputfile, header='', separator=' ')¶

Writes data to an ASCII file.

compare_synphot_files Module¶

plotting Module¶

A class to plot COS instrument handbook plots. Each figure is generated by it’s own function.

Note that the same function can be used to generate multiple figures of similar type.

@author: Sami-Matias Niemi (niemi@stsci.edu) for STScI

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.plotting.Fix(data, smooth=True)¶

Simple function to separate 1st and 2nd-order light from 230L.

class SamPy.plot.COSIHB.plotting.Plotting(filetype='.pdf')¶

A class to plot COS instrument handbook plots. Each figure is generated by a function.

AcqImageExposureTimes(data, output)¶

Fig. 7.3. in the COS IHB, version 1.0, page 72.

BOAMIRRORprofile(dataxx, dataxy, datayx, datayy, output)¶

Plots the cross-section through an image obtained with the BOA + MIRRORB in both x and y direction. Corresponds to Figs. 7.6 and 7.7 on page 75 at the first COS instrument handbook.

BOATransmission(datax, datay, every, output)¶

Plots transmission of the COS BOA as a function of wavelength. Corresponds to Fig. 3.4 on page 14 of the first COS instrument handbook.

BOAprofile(datax, datay, output)¶

Plots the cross-section through an image obtained with the BOA. Corresponds to Figure 7.5 on page 74 at the first COS instrument handbook.

COSFUVSpectrum(imagedata, wave, counts, exptime, output)¶

Plots an example of a COS FUV spectrum. Corresponds to Figure 4.2 on page 29 at the first COS instrument handbook.

COSFUVSpectrumDev2(imagedata, wave, counts, exptime, output)¶

Plots an example of a COS FUV spectrum with annotate. A bug in matplotlib version of STScI installation prevents using this...

Chapeter13Plots(datax1, datay1, boax2, boay2, title, output, G140L=False, logy=False)¶

Plots the FUV point-source sensitivities for Chapter 13. Old method, still used for NUV.

Chapeter13Sensitivity(psa, boa, title, output, G140L=False, logy=False)¶

Plots the FUV point-source sensitivities for Chapter 13.

Chapeter13SensitivityNew(psa, boa, disp, title, output, G140L=False, logy=False)¶

Plots the FUV point-source sensitivities for Chapter 13.

Chapter13SNPlot(data, stlim, grating, wavelength, output, FUV=True)¶

Creates signal-to-noise plots for COS instrument HB Chapter 15. Bright limit has been set for point source, should be changed if adapted for diffuse source.

Chapter13Wavelength(grating, offset, title, output, G140L=False)¶

Plots the FUV wavelength ranges for given grating setting.

Chapter13WavelengthNUV(grating, xoffset, title, output)¶

Plots the FUV wavelength ranges for given grating setting.

Chapter13WavelengthNUVNew(data, outputpath)¶

Plots the FUV wavelength ranges for given grating setting.

Chapter13WavelengthOLD(grating, offset, title, output, G140L=False)¶

Plots the FUV wavelength ranges for given grating setting.

Chapter13Waves(data, grating, output)¶
Chapter13WavesOLD(data, grating, output)¶
DispersedLightAcquisitionTimes(data, gratings, output)¶

Fig. 8.9 in COS IHB, version 2.0, draft 1

FUVFlatField(datax, datay, yline, output, smooth=False, smoothing=(50, ))¶

Plots the NUV MAMA flat field. Corresponds to Figure 5.6 on page 53 at the first COS instrument handbook.

FUVsensitivity(G130, G160, G140, output)¶

Plots FUV point-source sensitivities in units of effective area and throughput.

FUVsensitivityBOA(datax1, datay1, datax2, datay2, datax3, datay3, output)¶

Plots the FUV BOA point-source sensitivities for three gratings.

FUVsensitivityOLD(datax1, datay1, datax2, datay2, datax3, datay3, output)¶

Plots the FUV point-source sensitivities for three grating. Corresponds to Figure 5.2 on page 40 at the first COS instrument handbook.

LSFcomparison(data, waves, title, output)¶

Line Spread Function Comparison plots for Chapter 13.

MIRRORB(datax, datay, output)¶

Plots the cross-section of a point-source image with MIRRORB. Corresponds to Figure 7.4 on page 73 at the first COS instrument handbook.

NUVFlatField(datax, datay, yline, output, smooth=False, smoothing=(20, ))¶

Plots the NUV MAMA flat field. Corresponds to Figure 5.6 on page 53 at the first COS instrument handbook.

NUVImageProfile(xpixels, counts, output)¶

Plots NUV imaging profile for COS. Corresponds to Fig. 6.3 on page 63 at the first COS instrument handbook.

NUVPSAImagingSensitivity(datax, datay, output)¶

Plots the sensitivity curve for COS NUV imaging with the PSA. Corresponds to Fig. 6.1 on page 61 at the first COS instrument handbook.

NUVsensitivity(G185, G225, G285, G230, output)¶

Plots NUV point-source sensitivities in units of effective area and throughput.

NUVsensitivityG230L(datax, datay, output)¶

Plots NUV point-source sensitivities for grating G230L. Corresponds to Figure 5.4 on page 41 at the first COS instrument handbook.

NUVsensitivityM(datax1, datay1, datax2, datay2, datax3, datay3, output)¶

Plots NUV point-source sensitivities for M gratings. Corresponds to Figure 5.3 on page 41 at the first COS instrument handbook.

PSAMMIRRORANUVImaging(datax, datay, output)¶

Test function to plot cross section through and image.

PSARelativeTransmission(datax, datay, output)¶

Plots the relative transmission of the COS PSA at 1450A. Corresponds to Fig. 7.1 on page 69 at the first COS instrument handbook.

PSF(datax, datay, dataz, output)¶

Does not do very good job with matplotlib 0.99.0. The labels are somewhat tilted respect to the axis.

PSFObsolete(data, output)¶

Surface plotting with Gnuplot. Output is horrible... do NOT use!

ScatteredLight(datax, datay, output)¶

Plots the scattered light in the FUV. Corresponds to Fig. 5.1 on page 39 at the first COS instrument handbook.

SpatialProfileFUV(corrtag_data, disp, xvalues, width, ymin, ymax, extr, ewidth, title, output)¶
WavecalSpecPSA(wave, countss, output)¶

Plots and example wavecal spectrum of PSA FUV. Corresponds to Figures 13.3 and 13.4 on page 138 of the fist COS instrument handbook.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.plotting.Sensitivity2EffectiveArea(sensitivity, wavelength, dispersion)¶
SamPy.plot.COSIHB.plotting.Sensitivity2EffectiveAreaForArrays(wave, sens, disp)¶
SamPy.plot.COSIHB.plotting.Smooth(wave, eff)¶

synphotSensitivity Module¶

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.Chapeter15Sensitivity(data, boafile, dispersion, grating, title, output)¶

Plots the point-source sensitivities for Chapter 15.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.Chapeter15SensitivityNewG130M(data, boafile, dispersion, grating, title, output)¶

Plots the point-source sensitivities for Chapter 15.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.FUVsensitivity(G130, G160, G140, output)¶

Plots FUV point-source sensitivities in units of effective area and throughput. Used in Chapter 6 of COS IHB, version 2.0.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.NUVsensitivity(G185, G225, G285, G230, output)¶

Plots NUV point-source sensitivities in units of effective area and throughput. Used in Chapter 6 of COS IHB, version 2.0.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.findLatestFile(folder)¶
SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.fixThroughputs(data)¶
SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.main()¶
SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.multiplyThroughputs(data, ota_mirror, fuv_mirror='/grp/hst/cdbs/comp/cos/cos_mirrora_005_syn.fits', NUV=False)¶
SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.printSensitivity(data, dispersion, header, outfile)¶
SamPy.plot.COSIHB.synphotSensitivity.throughputs(files)¶

wrapperSynphot Module¶

This script works as a wrapper to create plots for the COS instrument handbook. Boolean variables in the main program can be set to False to limit the number of plots.

Calculation of zodiacal and earth shine background requires the use of local fits files (Zodi.fits and earthshine.fits). If these files cannot be found the S/N ration related plots of chapter 15 cannot be done.

This wrapper should always be accompanied with plotting.py which contains a plotting class. This class holds all the plotting functions and is required for running this wrapper.

@note: This wrapper superseeds wrapper.py

@author: Sami-Matias Niemi (niemi@stsci.edu) for STScI

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.FUVSensitivityDataMod(data)¶

Modifies the table containing FUV sensitivity data. Goes through the table and pulls out wavelength and sensitivity information. Goes through both sides (A and B). For the latter channel checks that the wavelength is not 50A, which is inside the gap. Makes sure that the saved wavelengths are not smaller than the first recorded wavelength of the side A. The function could be made faster with array manipulations rather than looping through the data.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.NUVSensitivityDataMod(data, smoothing, median=True)¶

Manipulates NUV sensitivity data. Pulls out all central wavelengths for all three stripes. Arranges the data with ascending wavelength.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.NUVSensitivityDataMod2(data, stepsize, Median=True)¶

Manipulates NUV sensitivity data. Finds either the min flux value with given wavelength or takes the median of fluxes at given wavelength.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.STMagToFlux(STMag)¶

Returns: NumPy array of fluxes.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.calculateSTMAGlim(global_limit, grating, sensitivity, gain=1, NUV=False)¶

A fugdge factor of 96% for encircled energy fraction is being used. These integration times are so short that we can ignore everything else but source counts.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.collapseSpectrumX(imagedata, xline, width)¶

Collapses the spectrum in x (COS dispersion) direction and sums pixels over. @param xline: gives the center point of the spectrum. @param width: gives the number of (plus and minus) pixels summed over in dispersion direction. @note: This could be done easier with numpy.sum()

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.collapseSpectrumY(imagedata, yline, width)¶

Collapses the spectrum in y (spatial for FUV) direction and sums pixels over. @param yline: gives the center point of the spectrum. @param width: gives the number of (plus and minus) pixels summed over in spatial direction. @note: This could be done easier with numpy.sum()

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.fluxToSTMag(flux)¶

Returns: NumPy array of ST magnitudes

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.getDispersion(segment, grating, cenwave, fppos, fileData)¶

Return dispersion relation of a given configuration.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.getEarthShineBackground(wavelength, width)¶

Returns the Earth Shine background value at given wavelength range. Note: Uses hard coded file earthshine.fits, which must be present in the folder this function is called!

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.getZodiacalBackground(wavelength, width)¶

Returns the Zodiacal light background value at given wavelength range. Note: Uses hard coded file Zodi.fits, which must be present in the folder this function is called!

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.printOutSensitivity(data, dispersion, header, outfile, stepsize=50)¶
SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.selectSensitivity(wavelength, sensitivity, requiredWave, width)¶

Returns: Mean of the sensitivity within required wavelength region.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.setCoordinatesImagingData(imagedata, x=-1, y=-1)¶

Sets coordinates to imaging data. @return: x, y, value found from image data

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.signalToNoise(sensitivity, flux, time, Npix, Bsky, Bdet, gain=1.0)¶

Calculates signal to noise ratio when following variables are given: sensitivity, flux, exposure time, number of pixels, sky backgound, detector background, and gain. For photon counters gain = 1. Number of pixels is used for the background calculations while the sensitivity is used for calculating the total number of counts.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapperSynphot.signalToNoisePerResel(sensitivity, flux, time, resel, Bsky, Bdet, gain=1.0)¶

Calculates signal to noise ratio using total counts in resolution element. Input: sensitivity, flux, time, resel, Bsky, Bdet, gain = 1. Returns: Signal-to-noise ratio, source counts, source noise, dark current counts, sky, background, total noise

wrapper_OLD Module¶

This script works as a wrapper to create plots for the COS instrument handbook. Boolean variables in the main program can be set to False to limit the number of plots.

Calculation of zodiacal and earth shine background requires the use of local fits files (Zodi.fits and earthshine.fits). If these files cannot be found the S/N ration related plots of chapter 13 cannot be done.

This wrapper should always be accompanied with plotting.py which contains a plotting class. This class holds all the plotting functions and is required for running this wrapper.

@author: Sami-Matias Niemi (niemi@stsci.edu) for STScI

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.FUVSensitivityDataMod(data)¶

Modifies the table containing FUV sensitivity data. Goes through the table and pulls out wavelength and sensitivity information. Goes through both sides (A and B). For the latter channel checks that the wavelength is not 50A, which is inside the gap. Makes sure that the saved wavelengths are not smaller than the first recorded wavelength of the side A. The function could be made faster with array manipulations rather than looping through the data.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.NUVSensitivityDataMod(data, smoothing, median=True)¶

Manipulates NUV sensitivity data. Pulls out all central wavelengths for all three stripes. Arranges the data with ascending wavelength.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.NUVSensitivityDataMod2(data, stepsize, Median=True)¶

Manipulates NUV sensitivity data. Finds either the min flux value with given wavelength or takes the median of fluxes at given wavelength.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.STMagToFlux(STMag)¶

Returns: NumPy array of fluxes.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.collapseSpectrumX(imagedata, xline, width)¶

Collapses the spectrum in x (COS dispersion) direction and sums pixels over. xline gives the center point of the spectrum. width gives the number of (plus and minus) pixels summed over in dispersion direction.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.collapseSpectrumY(imagedata, yline, width)¶

Collapses the spectrum in y (spatial for FUV) direction and sums pixels over. yline gives the center point of the spectrum. width gives the number of (plus and minus) pixels summed over in spatial direction.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.fluxToSTMag(flux)¶

Returns: NumPy array of ST magnitudes

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.getDispersion(segment, grating, cenwave, fppos, fileData)¶

Return dispersion relation of a given configuration.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.getEarthShineBackground(wavelength, width)¶

Returns the Earth Shine background value at given wavelength range. Note: Uses hard coded file earthshine.fits, which must be present in the folder this function is called!

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.getZodiacalBackground(wavelength, width)¶

Returns the Zodiacal light background value at given wavelength range. Note: Uses hard coded file Zodi.fits, which must be present in the folder this function is called!

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.printOutSensitivity(data, dispersion, header, outfile, stepsize=50)¶
SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.selectSensitivity(wavelength, sensitivity, requiredWave, width)¶

Returns: Mean of the sensitivity within required wavelength region.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.setCoordinatesImagingData(imagedata, x=-1, y=-1)¶

Sets coordinates to imaging data. Returns: x, y, value found from image data

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.signalToNoise(sensitivity, flux, time, Npix, Bsky, Bdet, gain=1.0)¶

Calculates signal to noise ratio when following variables are given: sensitivity, flux, exposure time, number of pixels, sky backgound, detector background, and gain. For photon counters gain = 1. Number of pixels is used for the background calculations while the sensitivity is used for calculating the total number of counts.

SamPy.plot.COSIHB.wrapper_OLD.signalToNoisePerResel(sensitivity, flux, time, resel, Bsky, Bdet, gain=1.0)¶

Calculates signal to noise ratio using total counts in resolution element. Input: sensitivity, flux, time, resel, Bsky, Bdet, gain = 1. Returns: Signal-to-noise ratio, source counts, source noise, dark current counts, sky, background, total noise
